comments:
This final clinical nursing course focuses on the integration and synthesis of scientific knowledge with clinical nursing practice and the development of the professional nursing role. Building on content from prior courses, students will develop an understanding of management of patient care from the perspective of the individual client and family to groups of clients and eventually to management of health care systems. Principles of leadership, accountability and change will be integrated throughout. The process of transition from the student role to that of the professional nurse will be facilitated through discussion of organizational systems, professional issues, mechanisms for evaluation of care and the role of the nurse as patient advocate and change agent. Students will select from several practice options for the clinical content of the course. Clinical seminar content will build on core content and will provide an exposure to advanced nursing concepts within the area of specialty practice. Application of conceptual models to clinical practice will be discussed and nursing research will be integrated throughout the course.

The class content is divided into two portions. The first meeting of the week is dedicated to case studies that students described as “excellent” and the “highlight of the course.” The second session was a lecture component, which many students found to be less informative and that the content was “review” from earlier courses in the nursing curriculum. However, the preparation for career classes that the course provided was “helpful.”

Professor Rogers was “so helpful in helping (students) transition towards practice.” Students were “impressed with the respect {Professor Rogers} had for the students.” The general opinion was that Professor Rogers was very accommodating and accessible.

According to students, there could be a stronger value put on “practical” values instead of “common sense.” The assignments were described as “busy work.” Many students felt the exam was not “a good reflection of what the class itself was.” This is a required course for nursing students and is taken during their senior year. The pre-requisite courses are NURS 321, 322, 340, 341 and the co-requisite course is NURS371.

Building on content from prior courses, students will develop an understanding of management of patient care from the perspective of the individual client and family to groups of clients and eventually to management of health care systems. The class content is divided into two portions. However, the preparation for career classes that the course provided was “helpful.”

Professor Polsky was described as “especially open to meeting with students outside of class and advising them.” Most students commented on Professor Polsky’s accessibility and helpfulness in aiding students transition from student to professional nurse.
